intro: Tanacetum coccineum subsp. coccineum, commonly known as the redhead garlic chrysanthemum, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe. It is characterized by its finely divided, silver-gray leaves and small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in flat-topped clusters. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and prefers full sun to partial shade. It is often found in dry, rocky soils and is valued for its ornamental appeal and mild, garlic-like fragrance. This subspecies is closely related to other members of the Asteraceae family and is commonly cultivated in gardens for its aesthetic and aromatic qualities.
